output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of Digital Signal Processing, equipping you with the necessary knowledge to explore more advanced topics and real-world applications.
output.introduction: Welcome to Digital Signal Processing! This course will introduce you to the fundamental concepts and techniques used to process signals in the digital domain. No prior knowledge of signal processing is required.

chapters.description: What are signals? Types of signals (continuous, discrete, digital). Examples of signals in real life (audio, images, sensor data).
Amplitude, frequency, and phase. Understanding these fundamental properties is crucial for signal analysis.
Visualizing signals in the time domain. Understanding the relationship between signal shape and its properties.

modules.moduleTitle: Introduction to Signals and Their Properties

chapters.description: What are systems? Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) systems. Examples of systems (filters, amplifiers).
Understanding the impulse response of a system. The impulse response characterizes the system's behavior.
Introduction to convolution. How to convolve two signals. Convolution is the fundamental operation for LTI systems.
Why use the frequency domain? Understanding the frequency content of signals.
Introduction to the Fourier Transform. Transforming signals from the time domain to the frequency domain.
Visualizing signals in the frequency domain. Understanding the relationship between signal shape and its frequency content.

modules.moduleTitle: Introduction to the Frequency Domain and Fourier Transform

chapters.description: What are digital filters? Types of digital filters (low-pass, high-pass, band-pass, band-stop).
Basic concepts of filter design. Understanding filter specifications (cutoff frequency, passband ripple, stopband attenuation).
Examples of filter applications (noise reduction, signal enhancement, equalization).
